attributes.title: Boeing ran afoul of criminal settlement on 737 crashes, DOJ says
attributes.content:
The U.S. Department of Justice on Tuesday said Boeing (NYSE:BA) violated a legal settlement concerning the role of its employees in two deadly plane crashes. The claim exposes the plane maker to possible criminal charges.

Boeing (BA) in January 2021 said two employees misled federal authorities about the 737 MAX jet, and was granted corporate probation to avert prosecution.

The claim comes several months after a new Boeing (BA) 737 MAX lost a door panel shortly after takeoff, forcing an emergency landing. The plane was the same model involved in the earlier crashes.

Boeing (BA) in April told the U.S. Federal Aviation Administration that workers may have falsified records on the 787 Dreamliner jets.

More on Boeing

  • Is Boeing Stock A Buy Or A Sell After Earnings?
  • Boeing: All About The Cash Burn
  • The Boeing Company (BA) Q1 2024 Earnings Call Transcript
  • Boeing's deliveries hit two-year low in April at 24 planes
  • Boeing’s lockout of firefighters criticized by unions, lawmakers

attributes.title: Petrobras CEO Prates ousted by Lula after dividend dispute
attributes.content:
Petrobras (NYSE:PBR) -6.9% post-market Tuesday following news that CEO Jean Paul Prates was fired by Brazil President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva, to be replaced by Magda Chambriard, the former head of Brazilian oil and gas regulator ANP.

Prates became CEO in January 2023, shortly after Lula assumed the presidency, but the change at the top had been speculated for months because of a dispute over dividend payments.

The CEO's departure represents a victory for members of Lula's cabinet that were pushing for lower domestic fuel prices, smaller dividends and more capital spending to create jobs.

Prates' exit is "a deterioration of Petrobras governance and a downside risk for the investment thesis," Citi analysts Gabriel Barra and Andres Cardona write. "The new CEO arrives with the pressure to fulfill the investment plan and accelerate the capex expansion, which may negatively impact the company's dividend payment."

The Petrobras (PBR) board will meet Wednesday to discuss the proposed departure, the company said.

More on Petrobras

  • The Petrobras Absurdity: Yield Exceeds P/E
  • Petrobras: We Shouldn't Be Unnerved By The Overblown Dividend Crisis
  • Petrobras: Repeating Past Mistakes, I Don't Recommend Buying Shares

attributes.title: Exxon makes new oil discovery offshore Angola - S&P Global
attributes.content:
Exxon Mobil (NYSE:XOM) has found oil at its Likembe-01 research well in Angola's offshore Block 15, two years after the last discovery on the license, S&P Global Insights reported Tuesday.

Angola's energy regulator reportedly said the well was drilled between February and April to a maximum water depth of 3,013 meters.

Likembe-01 is the first well to be drilled as part of an incremental production initiative by Angola to boost crude output from existing oil and gas projects in a bid to reverse years of production declines.

Exxon (XOM) operates the block with a 40% interest, alongside partners Sonangol, Equinor (EQNR) and BP-Eni (BP) (E) joint venture Azule Energy; it is one of three deepwater blocks held by Exxon offshore Angola.

Separately, Exxon (XOM) is preparing to drill an exploratory deepwater oil well ~500 km off the east coast of Newfoundland, Canadian Press reports.

The well will be drilled in the offshore Orphan Basin, which is north of the Flemish Pass Basin, where Equinor (EQNR) is considering developing the Bay du Nord project, which would be Canada's first deepwater oil production operation.

More on Exxon Mobil

  • Exxon Mobil Stock Is Not As Overvalued As You May Think
  • Exxon Mobil: Not Cheap, Still A Buying Opportunity
  • Exxon Mobil Plays It Safe With Hydrocarbons, Sidelines Direct Air Capture

attributes.title: U.S. appeals court upholds biofuel blending targets for 2020-22, rejecting refiners
attributes.content:
The District of Columbia Circuit Court of Appeals issued a ruling Tuesday upholding the Biden administration's biofuel blending requirements for 2020-22 under the Renewable Fuel Standard, rejecting a challenge by oil refiners.

The ruling left intact a 2022 rule set by the Environmental Protection Agency that required renewable fuel blending to rise to 20.63B gallons for that year, as well as retroactive volume mandates for 2021 at 18.84B gallons and for 2020 at 17.13B gallons.

For the first time under the RFS, the rule had used a new formula that tried to avoid a recurring situation in which the EPA failed to account for requests for exemptions by small refineries.

Oil refiners challenged the rule, arguing the standards were too high, while producers of biofuels derived from wood waste and other feedstocks also challenged the rule, saying the standards were too low.

Potentially relevant stocks include Valero Energy (NYSE:VLO), Exxon Mobil (XOM), Archer-Daniels-Midland (ADM), Green Plains (GPRE), REX American Resources (REX), LyondellBasell (LYB), Aemetis (AMTX) and Gevo (GEVO).

More on Valero Energy

  • If You Like Buybacks (And Dividends), You'll Love Valero
  • Valero Energy: On The March For Summer
  • Crack Spreads Continue To Support Valero Energy Stock

attributes.title: Seth Klarman's Baupost cuts Warner Bros. stake, takes in SoundHound, among others
attributes.content:
Billionaire investor Seth Klarman's Baupost Group cut its stake in Warner Bros. Discovery (NASDAQ:WBD), exited its position in Tower Semiconductor (NASDAQ:TSEM) and snapped up some shares in SoundHound AI (NASDAQ:SOUN) in Q1 2024, among other changes.

Baupost disclosed the information in its latest 13F filing for the three months ended March 31, 2024, published on Tuesday.

The fund slashed its Warner Bros. (WBD) holding to 3.71M series A shares in Q1 from 25.24M in Q4 2023. The entertainment company last week reported a quarterly top and bottom line miss, driven by revenue declines in its studios and networks segments.

Other stake reductions include a 30.4% cut in infrastructure and engineering firm Jacobs Solutions (J) to 506.8K shares, a 19% decrease in building materials and products maker CRH (CRH) to 30.6M shares, and a 12.3% trim in financial services provider Fidelity National Information Services (FIS) to 5.58M shares.

Baupost disposed off its entire Tower Semiconductor (TSEM) stake of 2.71M shares. Other holdings dumped by the fund include biotech Finch Therapeutics (FNCH), emissions reduction firm Garrett Motion (GTX) and broadcaster Gray Television (GTN).

Baupost picked up 1.13M class A shares in SoundHound (SOUN), a voice artificial intelligence solutions provider.

The fund also raised its stake in nutrition supplements marketer Herbalife (HLF) by 33.6% to 2.24M shares.

Seth Klarman's Baupost Group manages nearly $30B across a wide range of asset classes, making it one of the largest hedge funds in the U.S. According to Forbes, Klarman's real time net worth is $1.3B.

Related stories

  • Warner Bros. Discovery's failed Suicide Squad game highlights industry woes
  • Tower Semiconductor Non-GAAP EPS of $0.46 beats by $0.07, revenue of $327.24M beats by $2.81M
  • SoundHound AI jumps as Wedbush says AI momentum is 'front and center'
  • Jacobs Engineering beats Q2 bottom-line estimates

attributes.title: Oil slides to nine-week lows after latest inflation disappointment
attributes.content:
Crude oil futures closed at its lowest since mid-March on Tuesday, following new data that showed inflation in the U.S. remains higher than expected and OPEC left its global oil demand growth forecasts unchanged for this year and next.

The U.S. reported a higher than forecast 0.5% increase in April for the Producer Price Index, leaving prices up by 2.2% Y/Y, compared with 1.8% after March's data.

Also, Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell said he expects U.S. inflation will keep declining through 2024 but warned he is less confident now, since prices rose more quickly than expected through Q1.

Investors will now focus on Wednesday's release of U.S. consumer price data, which is bound to spark further speculation on the Fed's policy path on interest rates.

Meanwhile, OPEC said in its monthly report that it continues to forecast oil demand will grow by 2.2M bbl/day in 2024 and by 1.8M bbl/day in 2025, the same as the group's previous estimates.

Prices were supported by the continued potential risks to supply from Mideast tensions and wildfires in western Canada.

Front-month Nymex crude (CL1:COM) for June delivery closed -1.4% to $78.02/bbl, and front-month July Brent crude (CO1:COM) ended -1.2% to $82.38/bbl, the lowest settlement for both benchmarks since March 12.

ETFs: (NYSEARCA:USO), (BNO), (UCO), (SCO), (UNL), (DBO), (DRIP), (GUSH), (NRGU), (USOI)

The consensus opinion is that OPEC+ will extend production cuts at its June meeting, but Goldman Sachs says recent mixed messages from Russia and Iraq suggest no final decision has been made yet.

"Based on recent inventory upside surprises and our model estimates, we now expect OPEC+ supply to stay lower for longer," the bank says, but its forecasting model suggests an extension of cuts is "not a done deal."

Goldman attributes a 53% probability that the cartel and its allies will extend output curbs and a 37% likelihood that they will increase production.

More on crude oil and energy stocks

  • An Alarming Trend Is Developing In U.S. Shale Oil Production (Part 2)
  • An Alarming Trend Is Developing In US Shale Oil Production
  • XLE: Double Digit Dividend Growth Should Be Sustainable

attributes.title: Teck CEO sees $3B in annual EBITDA at $5/lb copper; stock hits multiyear high
attributes.content:
Teck Resources (NYSE:TECK) closed +2.1% in Tuesday's trading to its highest in nearly 13 years after CEO Jonathan Price said the company expects to generate $3B in annual EBITDA if copper prices hit $5/lb.

Speaking at a Bank of America conference in Miami, Price provided a range of predictions for Teck's (TECK) annual EBITDA at different copper prices, with the lowest at $2B if copper trades at $4/lb, according to Reuters.

U.S. Comex copper (HG1:COM) touched a record $5.082/lb on the front-month May contract Tuesday before settling +3.1% at $4.9535/lb, an all-time closing high; U.S. copper futures are up 8.5% so far this month and 27.6% YTD.

ETFs: (CPER), (COPX), (OTC:JJCTF)

Freeport McMoRan (FCX) and Southern Copper (SCCO) also hit new 52-week high, +2.7% and +2.6% respectively in Tuesday's trading.

The world has gone cuckoo for copper, with focus on the metal enhanced recently by BHP's $37B offer to buy out rival Anglo American, but Price said Teck (TECK) is focused on executing its existing projects when asked whether the company would look to acquire any copper assets.

"There's a lot of discussion in the industry about buy vs. build," Price said, "and when people are looking at projects with capital intensities above $30,000/ton, perhaps buying capacity makes more sense."

More on Teck Resources

  • Teck Resources: We Still See Potential For Further Gains
  • Teck Resources: Solid Q1 With Copper Expansion Progressing
  • Teck Resources: Our Top Pick To Ride The Copper Boom

attributes.bio:
Meghavi Singh is an editor on the India news team of Seeking Alpha, based in Pune.

Before joining Seeking Alpha in 2020, she worked with HSBC Bank for 12+ years in the wealth management and Regulatory Reporting departments. Prior to HSBC, she began her career with Gridstone Research, a financial research start-up, as a research associate for a period of 3 years, tracking company events and financial results for the US Consumer Sector.

She has two daughters and lives in Pune, India.

Rob Williams is a senior editor at Seeking Alpha, covering the industrial sector. Before joining SA, Rob worked at Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc., Bloomberg News and Newsmax, among other places. He also helped launch the Budapest Business Journal and the Mexico City Business Journal.

Rob graduated from Cornell University in Ithaca, New York. He lives with his family near New York City.

Carl Surran covers energy, utilities, and natural resources for Seeking Alpha. He joined the company in 2010 after writing about investment and personal finance topics for over 20 years. Carl has a BA from Duke University and an MBA from Rollins College. He is married with one daughter and lives in Florida.

Anuron is a U.S. stock market reporter for Seeking Alpha. He covers the daily Wall Street report, while also writing analysis pieces centered around equities, Treasury yields, the Federal Reserve and the U.S. economy. He is based in Bengaluru, India.

Anuron joined Seeking Alpha in March 2022 from Reuters News, where he spent nearly six years and covered U.S. breaking news, India breaking news and the health and pharmaceutical sector.

Anuron graduated from Christ University in Bengaluru in 2013 and holds a triple undergraduate degree in journalism, psychology and English.
